poem:
### Consensus Shattered

In Paris' corridors,  
words like scattered leaves,  
a dance of tongues—  
discordant autumn.  
Mathilde, sharp as frost,  
splinters the quiet,  
a mirror hewn in defiance;  
no budget embraced,  
no wall unseen,  
history unwrites itself  
in the voice of one  
standing firm  
against the tide.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Europe live: Macron labelled ‘a defeated president’ as his PM faces no-confidence vote 5.01pm BST Mathilde Panot, for the hard-left France Unbowed, quickly shatters Attal’s hope for any consensus-based politics as she goes all out against Bayrou and his government. She says her group is pleased to “never endorsed a single one of your budgets,” accusing successive governments of “leading us into the wall.” “We do not share your diagnosis, and even less so your". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
